sub_sections.scope_note: This policy covers data processing activities that may have an effect in Switzerland and, where applicable, within the EU/EEA. Defining the scope comprehensively ensures users are aware of how their data is handled across all interactions with the Platform and assists in our internal data governance by mapping data flows for each distinct functionality.

sections.title: Our Role: Matching Partner, Not Employer

sub_sections.title: Platform as an Intermediary
sub_sections.content: Interimed operates solely as a technology provider and an intermediary platform. Our primary function is to facilitate connections between users seeking professional opportunities (referred to as "Seekers," e.g., pharmacists, technicians) and users offering such opportunities (referred to as "Providers," e.g., pharmacies, healthcare institutions). The Services provided by the Platform are limited to offering tools for discovery, communication, access to contract templates, e-signature capabilities, calendar management, and related administrative functionalities.

sub_sections.title: No Employment Relationship or Service Leasing (LSE Compliance)
sub_sections.content:
It is explicitly stated and understood that Interimed does not employ Seekers and does not act as a "placeur" (private placement agent) or a "bailleur de services" (temporary work agency or service leaser) as these terms are defined under the Swiss Federal Act on Employment Services and the Hiring of Staff (LSE - Bundesgesetz über die Arbeitsvermittlung und den Personalverleih).
The LSE governs entities that, regularly and for remuneration, put employers and job seekers in contact for the purpose of concluding employment contracts (placement), or that cede the services of workers to third-party companies while retaining an employment relationship and transferring directive power (service leasing). Internet platforms can fall under the definition of a "placeur" if their activities meet these criteria. An activity is generally considered "régulièrement" (regularly) if there is an intention to offer such services repeatedly or if it occurs at least ten times within twelve months. "Contre rémunération" (against remuneration) is broadly defined and includes any payment whose cause is the placement, even the reimbursement of expenses.
Interimed does not enter into employment contracts with Seekers, either directly or on behalf of Providers. Furthermore, the Platform does not lease the services of Seekers to Providers, nor does it assume or transfer the essential powers of direction over a Seeker's work to a Provider in a manner that would constitute service leasing under the LSE. Any fees charged by Interimed are for the provision and use of its technological infrastructure, software tools, and intermediary services, and not as a commission for successful placement or for leasing personnel as defined by the LSE and its related ordinances (e.g., OEmol-LSE regarding fees and commissions).
Any contractual relationship, whether an employment contract, a mandate, or any other form of service agreement, is formed strictly and directly between the Seeker and the Provider. The Platform is not a party to such agreements. This distinction is critical, as activities qualifying as placement or service leasing under the LSE are subject to specific authorization requirements, financial guarantees (sureties), and operational obligations, from which the Platform, by its nature as a technology intermediary, is distinct.

sub_sections.title: User Responsibility
sub_sections.content: Users, both Seekers and Providers, are solely responsible for:
responsibilities: Verifying the accuracy, completeness, and authenticity of information provided by other Users on the Platform.
Conducting their own due diligence, including background checks or verification of qualifications, as they deem appropriate before entering into any agreement.
Negotiating and agreeing upon the terms of any contract between themselves.

Ensuring that any contracts entered into comply with all applicable Swiss employment laws, labor regulations (including those concerning working hours, minimum wages if applicable, social security contributions), tax obligations, and any other relevant legal requirements.
Fulfilling all obligations arising from such contracts.
sub_sections.responsibility_note: The provision of contract templates or e-signature functionalities by the Platform does not constitute legal advice or an assumption of responsibility for the content or legality of such user-to-user agreements. The features offered by the Platform, such as CV management, contract templates, and e-signature capabilities, are provided as tools to facilitate user interactions. However, users retain full responsibility for the content they input, the terms they agree to, and their adherence to all legal and contractual obligations. This reinforces the Platform's role as a neutral technology provider rather than an active participant in the contractual relationships formed between its users.

sub_sections.title: General Categories of Personal Data Collected:
sub_sections.content: To provide and improve our Services, we collect various types of personal data. Under the Swiss nLPD/FADP, personal data refers to any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person. The data of legal persons is generally no longer covered by the revised FADP.

data_categories.name: Identity Data
data_categories.description: Includes first name, last name, username or similar identifier, title, date of birth, and gender.

data_categories.name: Contact Data
data_categories.description: Includes billing address, residential address (if provided), email address, and telephone numbers.

data_categories.name: Professional Data (primarily for Seekers)
data_categories.description: Includes curricula vitae (CVs)/resumes, diplomas, work certificates, qualifications, skills, employment history, professional licenses or registrations, references, and any work eligibility information (e.g., work permit status, if voluntarily provided by you for matching purposes).

data_categories.name: Company Data (primarily for Providers)
data_categories.description: Includes company name, company registration number, industry, business address, and contact details of representatives (which constitutes personal data of those individuals).

data_categories.name: Financial Data
data_categories.description: Includes bank account details and payment card information. This data is collected for processing payments for our Services and for facilitating transactions involving our designated Fiduciary Partner.

data_categories.name: Transaction Data
data_categories.description: Includes details about payments made to and from you through the Platform, details of the Services you have subscribed to or used, and information related to contracts initiated or managed via the Platform.

data_categories.name: Technical Data
data_categories.description: Includes Internet Protocol (IP) address, your login data (username, password), browser type and version, time zone setting and location, browser plug-in types and versions, operating system and platform, and other information about the technology on the devices you use to access our Platform.

data_categories.name: Profile Data
data_categories.description: Includes your username and password, preferences you set on the Platform, feedback you provide, survey responses, and your interests as indicated through your platform activity.

data_categories.name: Usage Data
data_categories.description: Includes information about how you use our website, applications, and Services, such as features utilized, pages visited, content interacted with, and clickstream data.

data_categories.name: Calendar Data
data_categories.description: If you use our calendar management functionalities, this includes information such as event titles, descriptions, dates and times, attendee information (names, email addresses), schedules, and shared availability information.

data_categories.name: Contract Data
data_categories.description: Includes the content of contracts or agreements that you upload, create, manage, or electronically sign using our Platform's functionalities. This encompasses the names of the parties, the terms and conditions, and the e-signature data itself (which may include a visual representation of a signature, timestamps, and IP addresses associated with the signing event).

data_categories.name: Sensitive Personal Data (as defined by nLPD/FADP, Art. 5 lit. c)
data_categories.description: The nLPD defines sensitive personal data to include data on religious, philosophical, political or trade union-related views or activities; health; the intimate sphere; racial or ethnic origin; genetic data; and biometric data that uniquely identifies a natural person; and data on administrative or criminal proceedings and sanctions. We do not intentionally collect sensitive personal data unless it is directly provided by you (e.g., if a Seeker includes such information in their CV) or is necessary for a specific service with your explicit consent. For instance, a photograph on a CV, if used for unique identification, could be considered biometric data. Users are advised not to include unnecessary sensitive personal data in documents they upload. If such data is incidentally collected or inferred, we will handle it with heightened care and in accordance with applicable legal requirements.

sub_sections.title: Specific Mention of CVs, Diplomas, Work Certificates:
sub_sections.content: We explicitly collect CVs, diplomas, work certificates, and similar professional documents from Seekers. These documents are fundamental to the matching services offered by the Platform, enabling Seekers to present their qualifications to Providers. You, as a Seeker, control the content of these documents. We acknowledge that these documents can contain a wide array of personal information, and potentially sensitive data if you choose to include it (e.g., a photograph that might reveal ethnic origin, marital status, or nationality if it's not directly relevant but included by you). The processing of these documents is based on your consent when you upload them and your instruction to make them available for matching purposes.

sections.title: How We Collect Your Personal Data

sub_sections.title: Directly from You:
sub_sections.content: We collect personal data directly when you:
collection_methods: Register for an account on the Platform.
Create, complete, or update your user profile (whether as a Seeker or a Provider).
Upload documents such as CVs, diplomas, work certificates, or contract drafts.
Fill in forms on our Platform, including those for service requests or contact inquiries.
Use communication features available on the Platform to interact with other users or with us.
Configure calendar settings, create events, or respond to invitations using our calendar management tools.
Provide billing, payment, or financial information for transactions.
Contact our customer support or make other inquiries via email, phone, or platform messaging.
Participate in surveys or provide feedback.

sub_sections.title: Automatically When You Use Our Services:
sub_sections.content: As you interact with our Platform, we may automatically collect Technical Data and Usage Data:

automatic_collection_methods.name: Log Files
automatic_collection_methods.description: Our servers automatically record information created by your use of the Services. Log data may include your IP address, browser type, operating system, the referring web page, pages visited, location, your mobile carrier, device information, search terms, and cookie information.

automatic_collection_methods.name: Cookies and Similar Tracking Technologies
automatic_collection_methods.description: We use cookies and similar technologies (e.g., web beacons, pixels) to collect information about your Browse activities and preferences. These technologies help us operate the Platform, enhance user experience, perform analytics, and for security purposes. Detailed information on our use of cookies is provided in Section VII (Cookies and Tracking Technologies) of this policy.

automatic_collection_methods.name: Usage Data
automatic_collection_methods.description: We collect data on how you interact with specific features of the Platform, the functionalities you use, the time, frequency, and duration of your activities.

automatic_collection_methods.name: Device Information
automatic_collection_methods.description: We may collect information about the specific device you are using to access the Platform, such as hardware model, operating system version, unique device identifiers, and mobile network information.

sub_sections.automatic_collection_note: The automatic collection of Technical and Usage Data, often facilitated by cookies or analytics tools, is subject to stringent transparency and, for non-essential tracking, requires user consent or a clear opt-out mechanism as mandated by the nLPD and the Swiss Telecommunications Act (TCA).

sub_sections.title: From Third Parties:
sub_sections.content: We may receive personal data about you from various third parties, including:
third_party_sources: Our Designated Fiduciary Partner: In connection with the mandatory fiduciary services required for certain transactions on the Platform (as detailed in our Terms of Service), we may receive personal data from our Fiduciary Partner that is necessary for the provision, administration, or reconciliation of those services. This may include transaction confirmations or identity verification details.
Payment Processors: If you make payments for our Services, we may receive transaction details from our payment processing partners.
Analytics Providers: We may receive aggregated or de-identified analytical data from third-party analytics services that help us understand platform usage and improve our Services.
Other Users: For example, a Provider might initiate a contract with a Seeker, thereby providing some of the Seeker's data if not already on the platform, or vice-versa.
sub_sections.third_party_note: If the Platform integrates third-party authentication services (e.g., "Sign in with Google"), data received from these services will be clearly disclosed at the point of connection, along with the purpose (e.g., pre-filling profile information) and the legal basis (typically your consent).

sections.title: How and Why We Use Your Personal Data (Purposes and Legal Bases)
sections.content:
We process your personal data for specific purposes and only when we have a valid legal basis to do so under the Swiss nLPD/FADP and, if applicable, the GDPR. The nLPD/FADP generally permits data processing if it adheres to fundamental data protection principles; however, if these principles are potentially infringed (e.g., processing disproportionate to the purpose, or lack of transparency), a specific justification is required, such as your consent, the necessity for contract performance, a legal obligation, or an overriding legitimate interest. The GDPR strictly requires a lawful basis for all processing activities.
The following table summarizes our main data processing activities:

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: A. Providing and Managing Your Account and Platform Services (General Use)
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity, Contact, Technical, Profile, Usage Data
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To register and authenticate users, provide access to platform features, maintain and secure the platform, enable core matching functionalities, and personalize user experience based on preferences.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (Terms of Service); Overriding Legitimate Interest (security, platform improvement, basic personalization); Consent (for specific, non-essential personalization features).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Performance of Contract (Art. 6(1)(b)); Legitimate Interest (Art. 6(1)(f)); Consent (Art. 6(1)(a)) for non-essential personalization.

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: B. Processing Billing Information and Payments
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To process payments for subscriptions or other services, manage invoices, prevent fraud, and comply with financial and accounting regulations.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract; Legal Obligation (e.g., accounting/tax laws like Swiss Code of Obligations Art. 958f).

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: C. Facilitating Contract Management and E-Signatures
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity and Contact Data of signatories, Contract Data, Technical Data (IP address, timestamps, audit trails)
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To enable users to upload, manage, share, and electronically sign contracts; to provide a verifiable audit trail for e-signatures, ensuring compliance with e-signature laws like ZertES.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (providing the e-signature service); Consent (users actively use the feature for specific documents); Overriding Legitimate Interest (maintaining audit trails for security/dispute resolution).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Performance of Contract (Art. 6(1)(b)); Consent (Art. 6(1)(a)) for the act of signing; Legitimate Interest (Art. 6(1)(f)) for audit trails.

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: D. Managing CVs, Diplomas, and Other Professional Documents (for Seekers)
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Professional Data (CVs, diplomas, certificates, etc., which may contain Identity, Contact, and potentially inferred Sensitive Data)
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To allow Seekers to store their professional documents, build their profile, and share these documents with Providers for opportunity matching.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Consent (Seekers actively upload and choose to share); Performance of a Contract (providing profile and matching service). Explicit consent for any systematically processed sensitive data.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Consent (Art. 6(1)(a)), particularly explicit consent (Art. 9) if sensitive data is knowingly processed; Performance of Contract (Art. 6(1)(b)).

data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity and Contact Data of event participants, Calendar Data
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To allow users to schedule meetings, manage appointments, share availability, and send/receive invitations and reminders, facilitating interaction between Seekers and Providers.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (providing calendar tools); Consent (for sharing calendar access with specific users or for non-essential notifications).

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: F. Administering Fiduciary Agreements and Sharing Data with the Designated Fiduciary Partner
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity, Contact, Financial, Transaction Data, relevant Contract Data
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To facilitate mandatory fiduciary services (e.g., payment processing, holding of funds) provided by our designated Fiduciary Partner, including sharing necessary data with the Partner for service performance and their legal/regulatory compliance (e.g., AML/KYC).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (fiduciary agreement as a mandatory part of specific Platform services, per Terms of Service); Legal Obligation (for Fiduciary Partner's compliance); Consent (users agree to this as a condition of using services requiring fiduciary engagement, clearly outlined).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Performance of Contract (Art. 6(1)(b)); Legal Obligation (Art. 6(1)(c)); Consent (Art. 6(1)(a)) - must be specific and informed regarding this mandatory sharing.

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: G. Managing Contract Cancellations and Processing Cancellation Fees
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity, Contact, Transaction Data, Contract Data, payment information for fee
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To process contract cancellations as per agreed terms, calculate and collect applicable cancellation fees, and for record-keeping.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (cancellation terms and fees are part of the contract); Overriding Legitimate Interest (collecting owed fees, record-keeping).

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: H. Communication, Support, and Platform Improvement
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Identity, Contact, Usage, Technical, Profile, Feedback Data
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To communicate about account, service updates, policy changes; provide customer support; gather feedback; analyze platform usage for improvements, research, and development.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Performance of a Contract (service communications); Overriding Legitimate Interest (platform improvement, analytics); Consent (marketing communications, non-essential surveys).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Performance of Contract (Art. 6(1)(b)); Legitimate Interest (Art. 6(1)(f)); Consent (Art. 6(1)(a)).

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: I. Legal Compliance and Enforcement of Rights
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Any relevant personal data as required
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: To comply with applicable laws, regulations, court orders, or governmental requests; to establish, exercise, or defend legal rights.
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Legal Obligation; Overriding Legitimate Interest (protecting rights and interests).

data_processing_activities.activity_functionality: J. Profiling and Automated Decision-Making (If Applicable)
data_processing_activities.personal_data_categories_processed: Data used for profiling (e.g., Professional Data, Usage Data)
data_processing_activities.purposes_of_processing: E.g., to suggest matches, personalize services. (If such processing leads to automated decisions with legal or similarly significant effects, specific safeguards apply).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_nlpd_fadp: Explicit Consent if high-risk profiling (nLPD Art. 6(7)); Duty to inform if automated decisions (nLPD Art. 21).
data_processing_activities.legal_basis_gdpr: Art. 22 GDPR restrictions and safeguards; Explicit consent often required.

sections.legal_basis_note: The choice of legal basis for each processing activity is carefully considered. For core functionalities essential to providing the Services outlined in our Terms of Service, "Performance of a Contract" is often the primary basis. "Overriding Legitimate Interest" is relied upon for purposes like security and service improvement, always balanced against your rights and interests. "Consent" is sought for activities that are optional or go beyond the direct provision of contracted services, such as certain marketing communications or specific types of data analysis. If the Platform employs automated means to analyze or score professional documents (like CVs) for matching purposes, this could be considered "profiling" under nLPD (Art. 5 lit. g). Should this profiling be deemed "high-risk" (i.e., leading to a significant impact on individuals or involving extensive data), explicit consent will be sought as required by nLPD Art. 6(7). Any automated decision-making producing legal effects or similarly significantly affecting you will be subject to the rights and information obligations under nLPD Art. 21. The processing of data related to the Mandatory Fiduciary Partner (as detailed in section VI.F) is typically based on "Performance of a Contract," where the fiduciary service is an integral and essential component of the specific Platform service you have chosen to use, as clearly outlined in our Terms of Service. This contractual necessity means that to use these specific services, engagement with the Fiduciary Partner and the associated data sharing is unavoidable. We ensure transparency regarding this requirement at the point of engagement with such services.

sub_sections.title: Explanation of Cookies and Tracking Technologies Used
sub_sections.content: Our Platform uses cookies and similar tracking technologies (such as web beacons, pixels, and local storage) to enhance your user experience, ensure the functionality and security of our Services, analyze platform usage, and for other purposes described below. Cookies are small text files stored on your device (computer, tablet, mobile phone) when you visit our website. We categorize the cookies we use as follows:

cookie_categories.name: Strictly Necessary Cookies
cookie_categories.description: These cookies are essential for the operation of our Platform and enable core functionalities such as user authentication, session management, security features (e.g., preventing fraudulent logins), and enabling you to navigate the site and use its features. Consent is generally not required for these cookies under Swiss law, but we provide information about their use.

cookie_categories.name: Functionality Cookies
cookie_categories.description: These cookies allow our Platform to remember choices you make (such as your username, language, or the region you are in) and provide enhanced, more personal features.

cookie_categories.name: Performance/Analytics Cookies
cookie_categories.description: These cookies collect information about how you and other users interact with our Platform, such as which pages are visited most often, how users navigate the site, if error messages are received, and the overall performance of the Platform. This data is often aggregated and anonymized and helps us improve how our Platform works.

cookie_categories.name: Marketing/Targeting Cookies (If Applicable)
cookie_categories.description: If we use these cookies, they are typically set by us or third-party advertising partners to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant advertisements on our Platform or other websites. They track your Browse activity across websites. The use of such cookies will be subject to your explicit consent.

sub_sections.title: Information Provided to Users About Cookies
sub_sections.content: In line with the Swiss Telecommunications Act (TCA Art. 45c) and the nLPD/FADP, we provide you with clear and comprehensive information about our use of cookies and tracking technologies. This information includes:
information_provided: The identity of the data controller (Interimed) and any third parties that may set cookies through our Platform (e.g., Google Analytics).
The specific purpose of each cookie or category of cookies.
The types of data collected by each cookie.
The duration or expiry period of each cookie.
Information on any transfers of data collected by cookies to countries outside of Switzerland or the EEA, and the safeguards in place for such transfers.
sub_sections.information_note: This information is available through our cookie consent banner and in our detailed Cookie Policy, which is accessible via a link from this Privacy Policy and the banner.

sub_sections.title: Managing Your Cookie Preferences / Consent
sub_sections.content: You have control over the use of non-essential cookies. When you first visit our Platform, you will be presented with a cookie consent banner that allows you to:
consent_options: Customize your preferences and consent to specific categories of non-essential cookies.
sub_sections.consent_note: Strictly necessary cookies do not require your consent but you will be informed about them. For all other cookies, particularly those used for analytics, personalization beyond basic functionality, or marketing, we will seek your opt-in consent. You can change or withdraw your consent for non-essential cookies at any time. This can typically be done through a "Cookie Settings" or "Manage Cookies" link available in the footer of our website or within your account settings. You can also manage cookie preferences through your browser settings, which allow you to block or delete cookies. However, please note that blocking strictly necessary cookies may affect the functionality of our Platform. Our approach aligns with the FDPIC's guidance, which expects consent management platforms for more intrusive tracking technologies and clear opt-out options. We ensure that rejecting non-essential cookies is as straightforward as accepting them, avoiding "dark patterns" or pre-ticked boxes for non-essential cookies. Non-essential cookies are not activated until you provide your explicit consent.
sub_sections.detailed_list_note: A detailed list of cookies used, their specific purposes, providers, and durations can be found in our separate Cookie Policy, which we encourage you to review. Linking to a distinct Cookie Policy allows for more agile updates regarding specific cookie usage while maintaining the stability of this main Privacy Policy.

sections.title: Sharing and Disclosure of Your Personal Data
sections.content: We do not sell your personal data. We may share your personal data with third parties only in the circumstances described below and in accordance with applicable data protection laws:

sub_sections.title: Designated Fiduciary Partner (Mandatory Sharing)
sub_sections.content: As outlined in our Terms of Service, the use of certain functionalities on our Platform (e.g., secure payment processing for concluded contracts, management of specific contractual financial flows) requires the engagement of our designated Fiduciary Partner. To facilitate these mandatory services, it is necessary to share certain personal data with this Partner.

details.reason_for_sharing: This requirement is in place to ensure regulatory compliance (e.g., anti-money laundering (AML) obligations, payment services regulations), enhance the security of financial transactions, or is an integral part of the specific service structure offered.
details.data_shared: Categories of personal data shared may include Identity Data, Contact Data, Financial Data, Transaction Data, and relevant Contract Data necessary for the Fiduciary Partner to perform its duties.
details.purpose_of_sharing: Data is shared to enable the Fiduciary Partner to execute its contracted services, which may include identity verification (KYC/AML checks), payment processing, holding of funds in escrow, and fulfilling its own legal and regulatory reporting obligations.
details.legal_basis: The primary legal basis for this sharing is the Performance of a Contract (our Terms of Service with you, which incorporate the fiduciary services as an essential component of the specific services you choose to use). You are informed of this mandatory sharing and agree to it as a condition of using these specific services.
details.fiduciary_partner_privacy_practices: Our Fiduciary Partner is an independent data controller for the data they process for their own regulatory obligations. We encourage you to review their privacy policy, which will be made available to you, for information on how they handle your personal data.

sub_sections.note: The necessity of this Fiduciary Partner and the related data sharing is made transparent to you before you engage with services requiring their involvement.

sub_sections.title: Service Providers (Data Processors)
sub_sections.content: We engage reputable third-party service providers (data processors) to perform various functions on our behalf and under our instruction. These may include:
service_providers_list: Payment processing providers (for our platform fees, distinct from the Fiduciary Partner if applicable).
sub_sections.service_providers_note: These service providers are only granted access to the personal data necessary to perform their designated functions and are contractually bound by Data Processing Agreements (DPAs) to protect the confidentiality and security of your personal data, and to process it only in accordance with our instructions and applicable data protection laws. We conduct due diligence on our processors to ensure they provide sufficient guarantees for data protection.

sub_sections.title: Users on the Platform (Seekers and Providers)
sub_sections.content: The core purpose of our Platform is to facilitate connections between Seekers and Providers. Therefore, personal data will be shared between these user groups as an inherent part of the Services:
user_sharing_details: Seekers' Profile Data and Professional Data (including CVs, diplomas, certificates) will be made available to Providers with whom a Seeker chooses to interact or apply for an opportunity.
Providers' Company Data, opportunity details, and contact person information will be visible to Seekers interested in those opportunities.
Contact information and communication content will be shared when users interact through platform messaging or other communication tools.
Contract Data will be shared between the relevant parties when using the contract management and e-signature functionalities.
sub_sections.user_sharing_note: Users control the information they provide in their profiles and choose to share with other users. We remind users to exercise discretion and due diligence when sharing personal information with other users on the Platform.

sub_sections.title: Legal Obligations and Rights Enforcement
sub_sections.content: We may disclose your personal data if we are required to do so by law, regulation, a valid legal process (such as a court order or subpoena), or a binding request from a governmental or regulatory authority. We may also disclose personal data to establish, exercise, or defend our legal rights, or to protect the rights, property, or safety of Interimed, our users, or the public, as required or permitted by law.

sub_sections.title: Business Transfers
sub_sections.content: In the event that Interimed is involved in a merger, acquisition, financing, reorganization, bankruptcy, or sale of all or a portion of our assets, your personal data may be transferred as part of that transaction. We will notify you of any such transfer and any choices you may have regarding your personal data, in accordance with applicable law.

sub_sections.title: Anonymized or Aggregated Data
sub_sections.content: We may process and share data that has been anonymized or aggregated in such a way that it can no longer be used to identify any individual. This type of data may be used for research, statistical analysis, industry reporting, or to improve our Services.

sub_sections.title: Storage and Processing Locations
sub_sections.content: Your personal data is primarily stored and processed on servers located in Switzerland. However, to provide our Services, we may engage service providers (including our Fiduciary Partner) who are located or process data in other countries.

sub_sections.title: Adequacy Decisions
sub_sections.content: Switzerland, through the Federal Council, recognizes certain countries and territories as providing an adequate level of data protection (this list is found in Annex 1 of the Data Protection Ordinance - OPDo). This includes all EU/EEA member states and the United Kingdom. When personal data is transferred to these countries, no additional specific safeguards are generally required under Swiss law, as an adequate level of protection is deemed to exist.

sub_sections.title: Transfers to Countries Without Adequacy
sub_sections.content: If we transfer your personal data to a third country that is not recognized by the Swiss Federal Council as providing an adequate level of data protection (e.g., the United States, for certain service providers not covered by a specific adequacy framework like the Swiss-US Data Privacy Framework), we will ensure that appropriate safeguards are in place to protect your personal data. These safeguards typically include:
safeguards: Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs): We will use SCCs that have been approved or recognized by the FDPIC. This often involves adapting the EU SCCs with necessary amendments to meet Swiss requirements, such as ensuring protection for data of legal entities (where still applicable under transitional nLPD provisions) and providing appropriate jurisdiction for Swiss data subjects.
Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs): For intra-group transfers, if applicable, approved BCRs may be used.
Other FDPIC-recognized mechanisms: We may use other transfer mechanisms or guarantees as permitted under Art. 16(2) nLPD/FADP.
sub_sections.derogations_note: In certain limited circumstances, we may also rely on derogations as set out in Art. 17 nLPD/FADP, such as your explicit consent for a specific transfer after being informed of the risks, or if the transfer is necessary for the performance of a contract with you or in your interest.
sub_sections.fdpic_notification_note: Some transfer mechanisms, such as ad-hoc contractual clauses (Art. 16(2)(b) nLPD) or specific guarantees (Art. 16(2)(c) nLPD), may require prior notification to the FDPIC. We will comply with such requirements where applicable.

sub_sections.title: Our Commitment to Data Security
sub_sections.content: We take the security of your personal data very seriously. We have implemented and maintain appropriate technical and organizational measures (TOMs) designed to protect the personal data we process against accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure, or access. Our security measures are designed to be state-of-the-art and are regularly reviewed and updated in light of technological developments and evolving threats.

sub_sections.title: Examples of Security Measures
sub_sections.content: While we cannot disclose exhaustive details of our security measures for security reasons, our TOMs generally include:
security_measures: Data Encryption: Encryption of personal data both in transit (e.g., using TLS/SSL for web communications) and at rest (e.g., for data stored in our databases).

Access Controls: Strict access controls, including role-based access and strong authentication mechanisms (e.g., complex passwords, multi-factor authentication where appropriate), to limit access to personal data to authorized personnel on a need-to-know basis.
Network Security: Firewalls, intrusion detection/prevention systems, and other network security measures to protect our systems from unauthorized access.
Regular Security Assessments: Periodic vulnerability scanning, penetration testing (where appropriate), and security audits to identify and address potential weaknesses.
Data Backup and Disaster Recovery: Regular data backups and robust disaster recovery and business continuity plans to ensure data availability and integrity.
Secure Software Development: Integrating security considerations into our software development lifecycle.
Physical Security: Measures to secure physical premises and equipment where personal data may be stored or accessed.
Employee Training and Awareness: Regular training for our employees on data protection principles, security best practices, and their confidentiality obligations.
Incident Response Plan: A documented plan to respond to and manage data security incidents effectively.
Logging: Maintaining logs of data processing activities, especially for high-risk processing, for at least one year where required by nLPD.
sub_sections.note: Referencing established security standards, such as ISO 27001, can provide an indication of the framework guiding our security efforts.

sub_sections.title: User Responsibility for Account Security
sub_sections.content: While we implement robust security measures, the security of your account also depends on you. You are responsible for keeping your account login credentials (username and password) confidential and secure. We urge you not to share your password with anyone and to choose a strong, unique password for your account on our Platform. Please notify us immediately if you suspect any unauthorized access to or use of your account.

sub_sections.title: Data Breach Notification
sub_sections.content:
In the event of a data security breach that is likely to result in a high risk to your personality or fundamental rights, we will notify the Swiss Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner (FDPIC) as soon as possible, in accordance with Article 24 of the nLPD/FADP. If the breach is also likely to result in a high risk to you personally, we will notify you directly without undue delay, unless specific exceptions under the law apply (e.g., if the data was rendered unintelligible through encryption, or if the FDPIC instructs us otherwise).
Our internal incident response plan is designed to enable prompt assessment and, where necessary, notification in line with these legal obligations.

sub_sections.title: General Principles
sub_sections.content: We retain your personal data only for as long as it is necessary to fulfill the purposes for which it was collected, as outlined in Section VI of this policy. This includes retention for the duration necessary to provide you with our Services, as well as for satisfying any applicable legal, regulatory, accounting, or reporting requirements, or for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims. We adhere to the nLPD/FADP principles of storage limitation and data minimization, meaning personal data will be destroyed or anonymized once it is no longer needed for its original processing purpose, unless a longer retention period is required or permitted by law.

sub_sections.title: Specific Retention Periods (Examples)
sub_sections.content: The actual retention period for specific categories of your personal data may vary depending on the context and applicable legal obligations. Below are illustrative examples:

retention_examples.details: Your core account information (e.g., profile data, login credentials) is retained as long as your account remains active on our Platform. If you request to delete your account, or if your account becomes inactive for a prolonged period as defined in our Terms of Service, your personal data will be deleted or anonymized within a specified timeframe (e.g., 30 to 90 days), subject to any overriding legal retention obligations or legitimate interests (e.g., for dispute resolution).

retention_examples.data_category: CVs, Diplomas, and Other Professional Documents (Seekers)
details: If you, as a Seeker, secure a contract through the Platform, documents relevant to that engagement may be retained as part of the contractual record for the duration of that contract and for a subsequent period necessary for legal claims or as required by the Provider (who becomes the data controller for that employment/service relationship).

For Seekers who do not secure a contract or whose accounts are inactive, CVs and related professional documents will be retained for a defined period (e.g., 6 to 12 months) with your consent to facilitate ongoing matching opportunities. You can withdraw this consent or request deletion at any time. In the absence of ongoing consent or activity, or upon your request, these documents will be deleted or anonymized, in line with FDPIC guidance which generally advises returning or destroying unsuccessful application documents unless there is a legitimate reason or explicit consent for longer retention.

retention_examples.data_category: Contract Data (including E-signatures and associated audit trails)
retention_examples.details: Data related to contracts managed or signed using our Platform, including the e-signature audit trails, will be retained for the duration of the contract's validity and thereafter for a period necessary to comply with legal obligations (e.g., typically 10 years under Article 958f of the Swiss Code of Obligations if such data forms part of business books or accounting vouchers) or for the duration of statutory limitation periods for contractual claims.
Financial transaction data, invoices, and related billing information will be retained for 10 years, as required by Article 958f of the Swiss Code of Obligations for accounting records.

Calendar entries and associated data are retained as long as they are relevant for your scheduling purposes or until you choose to delete them. Older, non-essential calendar data may be periodically archived or deleted according to our internal data management policies.

Personal data processed in connection with fiduciary agreements will be retained in line with the legal and regulatory obligations applicable to our designated Fiduciary Partner (which may exceed 10 years for certain financial records) and our own record-keeping requirements.
Records of contract cancellations and any fees charged will be retained for 10 years if they form part of our accounting records, in accordance with Article 958f of the Swiss Code of Obligations.

System activity logs, security logs, and technical support logs containing personal data (e.g., IP addresses, user actions) are typically retained for a shorter period (e.g., 6 to 12 months) necessary for security analysis, troubleshooting, system integrity monitoring, and fraud prevention. For processing activities deemed high-risk under nLPD, logs may be kept for at least one year. Longer retention may occur if required for a specific security investigation or legal proceeding.

Records of communications with you, such as customer support inquiries, will be retained for a period necessary to resolve the inquiry and for a reasonable time thereafter for quality assurance, training, and record-keeping purposes (e.g., 2 to 3 years, though some contact form data might be kept for shorter periods like 13 months as per some practices).

sub_sections.retention_note: The 10-year retention period stipulated by the Swiss Code of Obligations for business books and accounting vouchers significantly influences the retention of any data linked to financial transactions or accounting processes on the Platform.

sections.title: Your Data Protection Rights
sections.content: Under the Swiss nLPD/FADP and, where applicable, the GDPR, you have certain rights regarding your personal data. We are committed to facilitating the exercise of these rights.

rights_list.name: Right to Information (Art. 19, 25-27 nLPD/FADP; Art. 13-14 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to be informed about how we collect and process your personal data. This Privacy Policy, along with any specific notices provided at the time of data collection, aims to fulfill this right.

rights_list.name: Right of Access (Art. 25-27 nLPD/FADP; Art. 15 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to request access to the personal data we hold about you and to receive a copy of it, along with information about the processing.

rights_list.name: Right to Rectification (Art. 32(1) nLPD/FADP; Art. 16 GDPR)
rights_list.description: If you believe that any personal data we hold about you is inaccurate or incomplete, you have the right to request its correction.

rights_list.name: Right to Erasure ('Right to be Forgotten') (Art. 32(2)(c) nLPD/FADP; Art. 17 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to request the deletion of your personal data under certain conditions, for example, if the data is no longer necessary for the purposes for which it was collected, or if you withdraw consent and there is no other legal ground for processing.

rights_list.name: Right to Restriction of Processing (Art. 32(2)(b) nLPD/FADP; Art. 18 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to request that we restrict the processing of your personal data in certain circumstances, for example, if you contest the accuracy of the data or have objected to processing.

rights_list.name: Right to Object to Processing (Art. 30(2)(b) nLPD/FADP for direct marketing; Art. 21 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to object to the processing of your personal data where it is based on our legitimate interests or for direct marketing purposes. We must then stop processing unless we can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds which override your interests, rights, and freedoms, or for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims.

rights_list.name: Right to Data Portability (Art. 28-29 nLPD/FADP; Art. 20 GDPR)
rights_list.description: Where processing is based on your consent or on a contract, and the processing is carried out by automated means, you have the right to receive the personal data you have provided to us in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and you have the right to transmit that data to another controller without hindrance from us.

rights_list.name: Right to Withdraw Consent (Art. 6(5) nLPD/FADP implicitly; Art. 7(3) GDPR)
rights_list.description: If we are processing your personal data based on your consent, you have the right to withdraw that consent at any time. The withdrawal of consent will not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Withdrawing consent should be...source as giving it.

rights_list.name: Right Not to Be Subject to Automated Individual Decision-Making (Art. 21 nLPD/FADP; Art. 22 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning you or similarly significantly affects you, unless such decision is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between you and us, is authorized by law, or is based on your explicit consent. If such automated decisions are made, you have the right to obtain human intervention, express your point of view, and contest the decision.

rights_list.name: Right to Lodge a Complaint with a Supervisory Authority (Art. 49 nLPD/FADP; Art. 77 GDPR)
rights_list.description: You have the right to lodge a complaint with the Swiss Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner (FDPIC) if you believe that our processing of your personal data infringes applicable data protection laws. If the GDPR applies to you, you also have the right to lodge a complaint with your local EU/EEA supervisory authority.

sub_sections.title: How to Exercise Your Rights
sub_sections.content: To exercise any of your rights listed above, please contact us using the contact details provided in Section II.B of this Privacy Policy. We may need to request specific information from you to help us confirm your identity and ensure your right to access your personal data (or to exercise any of your other rights). This is a security measure to ensure that personal data is not disclosed to any person who has no right to receive it. We will respond to your request within the timeframes stipulated by applicable law (generally within 30 days under nLPD/FADP and GDPR). In principle, information is provided free of charge, though a fee may be charged for manifestly unfounded or excessive requests, or if providing the information requires disproportionate effort.

sub_sections.title: Limitations
sub_sections.content: Please note that your rights are not absolute and may be subject to certain limitations or exemptions under applicable data protection law (e.g., if fulfilling your request would adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others, or if we have overriding legal or legitimate grounds to continue processing). We will inform you if any such limitations apply to your request.

sub_sections.title: Liability for Content of Contracts
sub_sections.content: Interimed may provide standard contract templates for the convenience of its Users. Users, such as Providers (e.g., pharmacies), have the ability to use these templates, adjust them, or add their own sections or entirely new contracts for the purpose of engaging with Seekers.Disclaimer: Interimed acts solely as a facilitator providing these tools. We are not a party to any contract entered into between Users. We do not provide legal advice, and the provision of contract templates does not constitute legal advice or an endorsement of their suitability for any specific purpose. Users are solely and entirely responsible for the content, legality, and enforceability of any contracts they create, modify, or agree to using the Platform's functionalities, including the e-signature service. We expressly disclaim any liability or responsibility for the terms, conditions, accuracy, completeness, or legal effect of any user-generated or user-modified contract content. Users should seek independent legal counsel to ensure any contract meets their specific requirements and complies with all applicable laws. Our processing of personal data contained within such contracts is solely for the purpose of providing the contract management and e-signature services as instructed by the Users involved.

sub_sections.title: Precedence of Platform's Standard Agreements in Disputes
sub_sections.content: This Privacy Policy, along with our Terms of Service and any other standard agreements published by Interimed (collectively, "Platform Agreements"), govern your use of the Platform and our processing of your personal data.Clarification: In the event of any conflict or inconsistency between the provisions of the Platform Agreements and any clauses implemented by Users within contracts they create or manage on the Platform (e.g., user-generated sections in a contract template), the terms of the Platform Agreements shall take precedence if the dispute involves Interimed or its designated partners (such as the Fiduciary Partner) and relates to the provision of the Platform Services, data processing by the Platform, or the interpretation of users' obligations towards the Platform, where specifically so stated in our Terms of Service. This ensures a consistent legal framework for the operation of the Platform and the protection of data processed by us. This does not affect the contractual obligations solely between Users, to which we are not a party.

sub_sections.title: Contract Cancellation Fees
sub_sections.content: When a contract facilitated through the Platform is validated and subsequently cancelled, a cancellation fee may be charged in accordance with the terms specified in the contract between the Users or in our Terms of Service if the fee pertains to Platform services. The calculation of this fee may depend on factors such as the timing of the cancellation relative to the contract start date. A minimum advance notice period for cancellation without incurring the full extent of such fees (e.g., 24 hours) may be stipulated.The processing of personal data related to the calculation, notification, and collection of cancellation fees (including Identity Data, Contact Data, Contract Data, and Financial Data) is undertaken for the purpose of enforcing contractual terms and collecting sums due. The legal basis for this processing is typically the Performance of a Contract (the agreed terms of cancellation) and our Overriding Legitimate Interest in recovering duly owed fees. Retention of these records will follow the principles outlined in Section XI, typically for 10 years if forming part of accounting records.

sections.title: Changes to This Privacy Policy
sections.content: We may update this Privacy Policy from time to time to reflect changes in our data processing practices, legal or regulatory obligations, or service offerings. The "Last Updated" date at the top of this policy indicates when it was last revised.If we make material changes to this Privacy Policy, we will notify you by appropriate means, such as by posting a prominent notice on our Platform or by sending you an email notification to the address associated with your account, before the changes take effect. We encourage you to review this Privacy Policy periodically to stay informed about how we are protecting your personal data. Your continued use of the Services after any changes to this Privacy Policy constitutes your acceptance of the revised policy.

sections.title: Governing Law and Jurisdiction
sections.content: This Privacy Policy and any disputes arising out of or in connection with it, including its interpretation and validity, or related to the processing of personal data by Interimed, shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the substantive laws of Switzerland, without regard to its conflict of law principles. The United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG) is excluded.Any dispute, controversy, or claim arising out of or in relation to this Privacy Policy, including the validity, invalidity, breach, or termination thereof, shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the competent courts of Geneva, Switzerland.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content:
Interimed is dedicated to protecting your personal data and ensuring transparency in its processing activities. This Privacy Policy outlines our practices concerning the collection, use, sharing, security, and retention of your personal data, in compliance with the Swiss nLPD/FADP and, where applicable, the GDPR.Key clarifications provided herein include:
- Our role is strictly that of a technology intermediary and matching partner; we are not an employer, private placement agent (placeur), or service leaser (bailleur de services) under Swiss law (LSE).
- Users are responsible for the content and legality of contracts they create or modify on the Platform.
- The mandatory engagement of a designated Fiduciary Partner for certain services necessitates specific data sharing, for which the legal basis and purpose are clearly defined.
- We have implemented technical and organizational measures to safeguard your data and have established procedures for data retention and the exercise of your data protection rights.
We encourage users to review this policy carefully. Should you have any questions or wish to exercise your rights, please use the contact information provided. Our commitment is to foster a trustworthy environment where users can confidently engage with our Services while their privacy is respected.
